Award.AwardTitle: The Geometry, Topology and Combinatorics of Hamiltonian Lie Group Actions
Award.AbstractNarration: Abstract<br/><br/>Award: DMS-0604807<br/>Principal Investigator: Tara S. Holm<br/><br/>The principal investigator's principal focus in this proposal is group<br/>actions and reduction in symplectic geometry. A fundamental problem<br/>in symplectic geometry is to relate the geometry and topology of a<br/>Hamiltonian system to the combinatorics of the moment polytope, and<br/>vice versa. The principal players on the geometric side include the<br/>symplectic manifold itself and its symplectic reductions.<br/>Combinatorially, the vertices, edges, k-dimensional faces, and even<br/>the chambers of the moment polytope play a significant role.<br/>Generically, a symplectic reduction has orbifold singularities. The<br/>principal investigator outlines a program towards understanding the<br/>geometry and topology of such orbifolds. These results will provide<br/>insight into the structure of the Chen-Ruan orbifold cohomology ring,<br/>yielding information about orbifold Gromov-Witten invariants. This<br/>work has also naturally led to foundational questions regarding group<br/>actions on orbifolds. Finally, the PI will distill the geometry and<br/>topology of the Hamiltonian system into combinatorial data associated<br/>to the moment polytope. This will shed new light on recent<br/>combinatorial results concerning intervals in the Bruhat order on any<br/>Coxeter group.<br/><br/>Symplectic geometry is the mathematical framework for describing<br/>phenomena in mathematical physics, from classical mechanics to string<br/>theory. The moment map is an important tool that translates the<br/>symmetries of a physical system into discrete data. An expert in<br/>symplectic geometry, the PI will achieve a deeper understanding of the<br/>relationship between the geometry of a symplectic manifold and the<br/>combinatorics of the moment map data. Her work will shed light on<br/>stringy invariants in this context. The proposed activities will<br/>advance our knowledge in the fields of symplectic geometry and<br/>combinatorics, with applications to algebraic geometry, algebraic<br/>topology and mathematical physics. The PI's broader objectives<br/>include increasing the participation and visibility of women in<br/>research mathematics, and enhancing the undergraduate experience in<br/>mathematics.<br/>
